entry.title: Identifying Disfluencies in Natural Speech | Google AI Blog
entry.summary: Posted by Dan Walker and Dan Liebling, Software Engineers, Google Research People don‚Äôt write in the same way that they speak. Written language is controlled and deliberate, whereas transcripts of spo...
entry.content: Posted by Dan Walker and Dan Liebling, Software Engineers, Google Research People don‚Äôt write in the same way that they speak. Written language is controlled and deliberate, whereas transcripts of spontaneous speech (like interviews) are hard to read because speech is disorganized and less fluent. One aspect that makes speech transcripts particularly difficult to read is disfluency, which includes self-corrections, repetitions, and filled pauses (e.g., words like ‚Äúumm‚Äù, and ‚Äúyou know‚Äù). Followin...

entry.title: Minerva: Solving Quantitative Reasoning Problems with Language Models | Google AI Blog
entry.summary: Posted by Ethan Dyer and Guy Gur-Ari, Research Scientists, Google Research, Blueshift Team Language models have demonstrated remarkable performance on a variety of natural language tasks ‚Äî indeed, a g...
entry.content: Posted by Ethan Dyer and Guy Gur-Ari, Research Scientists, Google Research, Blueshift Team Language models have demonstrated remarkable performance on a variety of natural language tasks ‚Äî indeed, a general lesson from many works, including BERT, GPT-3, Gopher, and PaLM, has been that neural networks trained on diverse data at large scale in an unsupervised way can perform well on a variety of tasks. Quantitative reasoning is one area in which language models still fall far short of human-level ...

entry.title: Market Data and News: A Time Series Analysis | KDnuggets
entry.summary: In this article we introduce a few tools and techniques for studying relationships between the stock market and the news. We explore time series processing, anomaly detection, and an event-based view ...
entry.content: In this article we introduce a few tools and techniques for studying relationships between the stock market and the news. We explore time series processing, anomaly detection, and an event-based view of the news. We also generate intuitive charts to demonstrate some of these concepts, and share the code behind all of this in a notebook.

entry.content: Posted by Jarrod McClean, Staff Research Scientist, Google Quantum AI, and Hsin-Yuan Huang, Graduate Student, Caltech In efforts to learn about the quantum world, scientists face a big obstacle: their classical experience of the world. Whenever a quantum system is measured, the act of this measurement destroys the ‚Äúquantumness‚Äù of the state. For example, if the quantum state is in a superposition of two locations, where it can seem to be in two places at the same time, once it is measured, it wi...

Trees in cities, called urban forests, provide critical benefits for public health and wellbein...

entry.title: Speed up Machine Learning with Fast Kriging (FKR) | KDnuggets
entry.summary: Machine Learning has revolutionized the world, yet expensive computation costs on model trainings are often a large limitation, especially for large data sets or elevated precisions. VMC Consulting of...
entry.content: Machine Learning has revolutionized the world, yet expensive computation costs on model trainings are often a large limitation, especially for large data sets or elevated precisions. VMC Consulting offers a new algorithm called Fast Kriging (FKR), which allows to train models with the high precision of Kriging at a speed 100+ times faster, without compromising precision, for any data set size.
